block.p: Both Sides in Mideast Seek To Rekindle Peace Process Amid a flurry of political and diplomatic moves, Israel and the Palestinians indicated that they wanted to put the failed Camp David talks behind them and press on with a renewed peace bid. The sides confirmed negotiators would meet on Sunday at the Gaza Strip border.

The sides confirmed negotiators would meet on Sunday at the Gaza Strip border.

New Details on Concorde Crash Flight recorders showed that the pilots of the Air France Concorde had problems with both left engines and could not retract the landing gear. The data also made clear that the plane was too far down the runway to abort the takeoff when the tower told the pilot flames could be seen.
Peru Prepares for Protests Riot police in Lima took up positions and vendors sold crude gas masks in advance of President Alberto K. Fujimori's third inauguration today.

Dissent Over Cardinal's Killing Mexican government and church authorities agreed to disagree about the events in 1993 that led to the killing of Juan Jesus Posadas Ocampo, one of Mexico's two Roman Catholic cardinals. Federal prosecutors maintain the cardinal was mistaken for a drug lord by traffickers.

Russia Halts Inquiry of Mogul Prosecutors dropped their criminal inquiry into Vladimir V. Gusinsky, the Russian press tycoon whose Media-Most empire has been among the Kremlin's sharpest critics. Prosecutors did not explain why they had abandoned the investigation.

Oil Bribery Investigation Swiss and American officials blocked Kazakhstan from access to bank accounts holding about $100 million that Western oil companies are suspected of using to bribe senior Kazakh officials, according to officials with knowledge of the action.

Milosevic Calls for Elections President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia called for presidential, parliamentary and local elections on Sept. 24. Opposition parties are divided on whether to participate.
New Government in Fiji The president announced an interim government that lacked supporters of the coup leader, George Speight, who might face treason charges.

G.O.P. Easing Stands, But Not on Abortion The proposed Republican platform would drop several of the more hard-edged conservative positions adopted four years ago -- like calling for the abolition of the Department of Education -- and transform much of the document's tone to reflect the ''compassionate conservatism'' of Gov. George W. Bush. But it also retains the call for a ban on abortion with no exceptions and the appointment of judges who ''respect traditional family values and the sanctity of innocent human life.''
Dick Cheney continued to respond to questions about his conservative voting record, and Gov. George W. Bush defended his running mate.

Pentagon to Put On a Show Despite a policy barring military involvement in politics, members of Congress and guests at the Republican National Convention will have an exclusive viewing of some of the Pentagon's latest hardware, including the the V-22 Osprey, above, which Dick Cheney opposed developing when he was defense secretary.
The Marines said two pilots of an Osprey would be disciplined for actions contributing to the fatal crash of a companion Osprey in April.

Gun Industry Advertisements The firearms industry plans to run commercials during prime-time coverage of the Republican convention next week attacking politicians, mostly Democrats, who back lawsuits against the industry.

Soft-Money Inquiry Sought Common Cause and Democracy 21 urged the Justice Department to investigate whether the two major parties were violating federal election laws by using large unregulated political donations to pay for television commercials promoting the Gore and Bush campaigns.

Water Plan Advances California and six other Western states that rely on water from the Colorado River have reached the outlines of an agreement for California to gradually reduce its over-dependence on the river.
Offer of Free DNA Testing The San Diego County district attorney has begun a policy of offering free DNA testing to inmates who say they were wrongly convicted.

No Indictment of Officer In Killing of Unarmed Man A grand jury declined to file criminal charges against the undercover narcotics detective who fatally shot Patrick M. Dorismond, left, an off-duty, unarmed security guard, in Midtown. The Manhattan district attorney said jurors had concluded that the killing was not intentional. Federal prosecutors are reviewing the case.
Since federal authorities began reviewing the police disciplinary process three years ago, the department has punished many more officers for a wide range of misconduct.
Gunman on Jet at Kennedy A man with a handgun walked into the cockpit of a jet at Kennedy Airport and took the pilot and co-pilot hostage. Both were freed and all passengers escaped unharmed.
Accusations of Census Fraud Census workers in the city and Westchester said supervisors pressed them to cut corners and submit fraudulent or incomplete data.
Spraying in Manhattan The city planned to begin ground spraying in Manhattan, concluding a weeklong campaign intended to stamp out the West Nile virus.
A New Greenhouse Gas Scientists have found rising levels of a newly identified synthetic gas that traps heat in air more effectively than other compounds released by industry and fuel-burning.
Seeking Water on Mars NASA plans to send one or two large robotic roving vehicles to investigate new evidence of water on Mars, either now on in the past.
Long-Term Effects of Pain A study showing that pain administered in infancy can permanently rewire the nervous system in rats may have implications for human infants, researchers said.

The Check Is in the Mail A failure to assign enough workers to move the mail and problems installing a new computer system for tracking certified mail have led to pileups of those letters -- which include tax payments and legal documents -- in postal warehouses from Manhattan to Los Angeles.

Cutbacks at Conseco The troubled insurance and finance company said it would cut 2,000 jobs from its finance operation and sell assets to raise cash to meet debt payments coming due. The company reported a quarterly loss of $404.7 million, or $1.25 a share.

No Corning-Nortel Deal Corning and Nortel Networks broke off talks that would have combined their fiber optic operations and given Corning, the world's largest maker of optical fiber, a relatively full line of the lasers and other components used in making state-of-the-art communications and data networks.

Protecting Net Privacy The F.T.C. reached an agreement with a group of Internet advertisers on how they glean information from Web surfers and what they do with it. Among the provisions, Web surfers will now be explicitly told of advertiser attempts to profile consumers and will be given the option of choosing not to participate.
